instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..

threads.title: [CLOSED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, Liquid, Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Repairing this board for a friend, but looking more and more like a bad PCH. I want to make absolutely sure before giving him the bad news.

Board had liquid all over, 7+ areas. Replaced obviously bad components. <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> was shorted; found <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> was shorted, replaced, and short on 3v42 was gone. Got green light. Fixed some burned traces in a few areas, and ppbus was very low. Replaced ISL, got solid 12.58v on ppbus. Now all S5 rails present (including <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>), but <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> is not present. VRTC is present everywhere it should be, and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> is also present. Resistance to ground on L7630 is 7.6ohm.

Is there anything else I can check before declaring this board irreparable (I can't replace PCHs)? Thanks for any help.

threads.title: [CLOSED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, Liquid, Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Was there liquid around <CHIP>U2600</CHIP>? If yes replace it. Check voltages on both sides of <RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR>-03?

threads.title: [CLOSED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, Liquid, Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hey Duke,

Thanks. I replaced the clock, even though there wasn't really any liquid nearby, and no change. Voltage is present at all of <RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR>/01/02/03 and they all measure out properly (and there was no liquid near them, etc). 

Thanks!

threads.title: [CLOSED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, Liquid, Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Crap under SMC maybe, it could be anything at this point.

threads.title: [CLOSED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, Liquid, Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thanks, Duke! Yeah I pulled the SMC and it was clean underneath; replaced it and same issue. I did notice, however, that I'm missing all T29 rails. I can't tell from the schematics, but at what point should these T29 rails show up? Is it after <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>? It seems they should be present at all times though, right?

threads.title: [CLOSED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, Liquid, Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: T29 is thunderbolt and of no interest. I have no more ideas then to check for corrosion, there is no easy solution.

threads.title: [CLOSED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, Liquid, Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thanks, Duke. Yeah this board had so many areas of liquid that it's likely a through-board trace or something that isn't visible. Would take too much time; I'll call this one closed and inform my customer-friend, thanks!
